story:
Short Summary

         I feel that the heart of a home lies nestled within the comfy confines of the kitchen. Most of my earliest memories involve sharing food with people I love. Truth be told, I love food and I love cooking. While it is novel to think about, not every meal has to be, or can be, grandiose. Sometimes you just want an old fashioned PB&J. With Squirrely's, you will get just that plus more. We will deliver multiple variations of the classic with a gourmet twist. 

         We will offer virtually any nut butter & jam combination you can think of. Best of all, the nut butters and jams will be handmade in small batches for maximum freshness. They will also be available to take home by the pound, so you can enjoy their deliciousness for days & days. In addition to the different sandwich options, we will feature various shakes & smoothies that will most certainly arouse your taste buds and fill your belly. Finally, simple snacks and rotating daily treats will satisfy your desire for mindful eating.  Out walking your dog? We will have homemade peanut butter dog treats for them too!



         EVERYTHING on the menu will be NON-GMO. We're pretty sure we will be the first truck in the world to feature such items, and we hope we aren't the last.  Squirrely's will also be predominantly ORGANIC! We care about where our food comes from and we promise to supply you with only the best ingredients possible. Gluten free bread will be available. Vegans will not be denied. Soy free? We got you! If you want to avoid canola oil, don't worry, because we do too! When it comes to protein shakes, we will feature 100% whey protein concentrate from grass fed cows. No protein isolates! There will also be a vegan plant based protein powder option. No artificial colors, flavors, or preservatives in ANY of our food. It will be nothing but pure, fresh, QUALITY nourishment. Perfect for any age!

         The long term plan is to transition and/or incorporate Squirrely's into a brick & mortar business. A relaxing cafe/bakery type atmosphere the whole family will love. Also, we would like to have our nut butters & jams sold at local farmer's markets, online, and at grocery stores across America. 

What We Need & What You Get

         We're asking for $12,000, although more is most certainly going to be needed. The money will go towards acquiring & outfitting the truck, purchasing equipment, and paying for necessary licenses & permits.
          Please take a look at the many perks we're offering. When you contribute, you get something in return.

Risks & Challenges

         The biggest challenge is going to be raising enough money in order to make this project successful. I'm confident that once we're up & running, our products will satisfy even the harshest critics. Other challenges include finding ideal spots that will allow us to park for a few hours while we work our magic to bring you delicious & nutritious foods.

Other Ways You Can Help

         If you aren't able to contribute financially, we understand. Times are hard for all of us. We ask that you simply share this link with others, or casually bring up our fundraising campaign whenever applicable.  Many, many thanks in advance!


Menu

BREADS:

  • White
  • Wheat
  • Gluten Free
  • Cinnamon Raisin
  • Plain Bagel

NUT BUTTERS:

  • Peanut Butter
  • Honey Roasted Peanut Butter
  • Almond Butter
  • Vanilla Maple Almond Butter
  • Sunflower Butter
  • Rotating Weekly Specials to Include: Ginger Peanut Butter, Dark Chocolate Cherry Almond Butter,  Cinnamon Vanilla Hazelnut Butter, Bacon Pistachio Butter, Cherry Coconut Butter, among others.

SPREADS:

  • Strawberry Jam
  • Grape Jam
  • Raspberry Jam
  • Homemade 'Nutella'
  • Cream Cheese
  • 100% Local Honey
  • Rotating Jams based on Local Availability
SPECIALTY SANDWICHES:
  • Peanut Butter, Bacon, Pickle & Sriracha 
  • Peanut Butter, Banana & Honey
  • Almond Butter, Fig Spread & Banana
  • Goat Cheese, Strawberry Jam, & Basil
  • S'mores
  • Weekly Specials

SIDES:
    (available with any butter or spread)

  • Apple (sliced or whole)
  • Banana
  • Celery sticks
  • Carrot Sticks
  • Pickles
  • Rice Cakes

*SMOOTHIES:
    (Your Choice of Almond, Rice, or Soy Milk)

  • Peanut Butter Chocolate
  • Peanut Butter Banana
  • Sharny's Post Workout: Banana, Blueberries, Ginger, Cinnamon, Ground Flax Seed, & Chocolate Whey Protein Concentrate blended with Almond Milk

  • Protein Shakes can be made with your choice of: 
          Whey Protein Concentrate or Vegan Protein Powder
  • Create Your Own, choose from:  
         Frozen Blueberry, Mango, Strawberry, Pineapple, Banana, Ginger Root,        
         Tumeric Root, Coconut Oil, Cayenne, Cinnamon, Vanilla, Himalayan Sea Salt,  
         Chia Seeds, Ground Flax Seed, Maca Powder, Goji Berries
  • Daily Specials
TREATS:
  • Fig Bars
  • Gluten Free Peanut Butter Cookies
  • Daily Specials
  • Peanut Butter Dog Biscuits
*Smoothies will have the option of being served in glass jars for an additional $1 deposit fee. Bring the jar back for a refund! 
All items will be served using recyclable and/or biodegradable packaging.
No styrofoam containers will be used. Customers are strongly encouraged to bring their own bags to carry large orders.

story:
TILIZINWE means 'We are together!' in Xitswa, one of the local languages on Bazaruto Island, Mozambique. TOGETHER, we hope to uplift the local Maxulane community of Bazaruto through education and skills-development.

WHY? Because we believe that education empowers - it enables people to make informed decisions about themselves, their environment, and their world. 

We believe that, given the knowledge and skills to do so, the local population on Bazaruto island can not only thrive as people and as a community, but also contribute to the conservation of their incredible paradise.


We foresee a time, not far in the future, where we will not only have a fully functional child-care and adult skills development centre which is operated by and for the local community, but also an operational clinic, working latrines and safe drinking water - ensuring a new generation of educated, healthy and skillful Islanders who are able to adapt to the constantly changing world.


What We Need

Currently, there are no health-care facilities at the Northern end of the island where the Maxulane community resides. In an area where malaria, contagious skin diseases and infections are common, the close proximity to which the local community members live to one another in their village results in these illnesses being easily spread.  Community members in need of medical assistance have to travel to the mainland by motorised dhow (local wooden boats), a trip that can take anything from 3 to 8 hours, weather depending.

The Tilizinwe Bazaruto community project's number one priority at this time is to get a fully functioning and staffed clinic for the community.  Through a successful auction held during the annual Marlin fishing competition at Pestana Bazaruto Lodge in 2013, Tilizinwe Bazaruto raised enough money to renovate the designated building into a usable clinic: with 2 wards, 2 bathrooms, a medical dispensary and a waiting area, but we need additional funding to purchase solar power and water reticulation systems.

       

 The USD 10 000 we hope to raise will be used for:

- A '4 solar panel + 4 battery' kit 

-  Water tank and tower   

-  2 x submersible water pumps 

-  Pump controller 

- Solar fridge for medicine that needs to be stored below room temperature

- Gas stove for boiling water 

- Gas bottles

- Employment of a local staff member who will be in charge of cleaning and maintaining the clinic

A generous donor from South Africa has donated the hospital beds and bedside cupboards, which are currently in transit to the island. Once the clinic is complete, the Mozambiquen Department of Health has committed to sending a medical technician to permanently reside on the island and staff the clinic.


Our gratitude

As a thank you, you will receive perks such as electronic pictures of our healthy and smiling Tilizinwe kids, signed local artwork, free tours around our village when you visit us, complimentary spa treatments when at Pestana Bazaruto Lodge, or your name on a plaque in the clinic!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t  contribute but would still like to help, please spread the word about our campaign  by pressing SHARE! The more people that are TOGETHER in this with us, the better our chances of reaching our goal:)


A little more info about our project

In order to achieve our goal of self-sustainability for the Maxulane community members of Bazaruto Island, we:

· Provide skills building classes to the community members (currently English classes and Portuguese literacy classes) in order to equip them with the tools necessary to seek out employment

                          

. Run a pre-school and supplementary school for the children of the community, in conjunction with the feeding scheme

                 

·  Run a sponsorship programme to send children to high-school on the mainland, since there are no facilities for  higher education on the island. We sent the first 5 children to high-school at the beginning of 2015, and hope to send at least 5 each year.

                                                        

· Encourage community members to engage in environmentally conservative practices by providing them with the knowledge to do so. One of the ways we do this is by running the Marine Megafauna foundations's 'Nemo's Pequeno's' swimming and conservation training programme with our community a few times yearly

               

· Initiate alternate employment and income generation opportunities in order to promote sustainability - such as the community vegetable garden, and locally guided village and lighthouse tours

                                                           

·  Conduct Fund-raising drives for the improvement of the standard of living of the community members: addressing the lack of basic facilities such as ablutions, a clinic and safe drinking water


THANK YOU....

..to everyone who has helped us get to this point, you have taken our project to where it is today.

...to Daan van Duinkerken for creating this beautiful video for our indiegogo campaign.  Music: "African" by Roberto80z (www.jamendo.com)

TILIZINWE means 'We are together!' in Xitswa, one of the local languages on Bazaruto Island, Mozambique. TOGETHER, we hope to uplift the local Maxulane community of Bazaruto through education and skills-development.
WHY? Because we believe that education empowers - it enables people to make informed decisions about themselves, their environment, and their world. 
We believe that, given the knowledge and skills to do so, the local population on Bazaruto island can not only thrive as people and as a community, but also contribute to the conservation of their incredible paradise.


We foresee a time, not far in the future, where we will not only have a fully functional child-care and adult skills development centre which is operated by and for the local community, but also an operational clinic, working latrines and safe drinking water - ensuring a new generation of educated, healthy and skillful Islanders who are able to adapt to the constantly changing world.
   What We Need 
Currently, there are no health-care facilities at the
Northern end of the island where the Maxulane community resides. In an area
where malaria, contagious skin diseases and infections are common, the close
proximity to which the local community members live to one another in their
village results in these illnesses being easily spread.  Community members in need of medical
assistance have to travel to the mainland by motorised dhow (local
wooden boats), a trip that can take anything from 3 to 8 hours, weather
depending. 
The Tilizinwe Bazaruto community project's number one priority at this time is to get a fully functioning and staffed clinic for the community.  Through a successful auction held during
the annual Marlin fishing competition at Pestana Bazaruto Lodge in 2013, Tilizinwe Bazaruto raised enough money to renovate the designated
building into a usable clinic: with 2 wards, 2 bathrooms, a medical dispensary and
a waiting area, but we need additional funding to purchase solar power and
water reticulation systems.



       
 The USD 10 000 we hope to raise will be used for:
- A '4 solar panel + 4 battery' kit  
- 
Water tank and tower    
- 
2 x submersible water pumps  
- 
Pump controller 
- Solar fridge for medicine that needs to be stored below room temperature
- Gas stove for boiling water 
- Gas bottles
- Employment of a local staff member who will be in charge of cleaning and maintaining the clinic
A generous donor from South Africa has donated the hospital
beds and bedside cupboards, which are currently in transit to the island. Once the clinic is complete, the Mozambiquen Department of Health has committed to sending a medical technician to permanently reside on the island and staff the clinic.



Our gratitude
As a thank you, you will receive perks such as electronic pictures of our healthy and smiling Tilizinwe kids, signed local artwork, free tours around our village when you visit us, complimentary spa treatments when at Pestana Bazaruto Lodge, or your name on a plaque in the clinic!


Other Ways You Can Help
If you can’t  contribute but would still like to help, please spread the word about our campaign  by pressing SHARE! The more people that are TOGETHER in this with us, the better our chances of reaching our goal:)

A little more info about our project
In order to achieve our goal of self-sustainability for the Maxulane community members of Bazaruto Island, we:

· Provide skills building classes to the community members (currently English classes and Portuguese literacy classes) in order to equip them with the tools necessary to seek out employment

                          
. Run a pre-school and supplementary school for the children of the community, in conjunction with the feeding scheme

                 
·  Run a sponsorship programme to send children to high-school on the mainland, since there are no facilities for  higher education on the island. We sent the first 5 children to high-school at the beginning of 2015, and hope to send at least 5 each year.


                                                        
· Encourage community members to engage in environmentally conservative practices by providing them with the knowledge to do so. One of the ways we do this is by running the Marine Megafauna foundations's 'Nemo's Pequeno's' swimming and conservation training programme with our community a few times yearly

               
· Initiate alternate employment and income generation opportunities in order to promote sustainability - such as the community vegetable garden, and locally guided village and lighthouse tours

                                                           
·  Conduct Fund-raising drives for the improvement of the standard of living of the community members: addressing the lack of basic facilities such as ablutions, a clinic and safe drinking water


THANK YOU....
..to everyone who has helped us get to this point, you have taken our project to where it is today.
...to Daan van Duinkerken for creating this beautiful video for our indiegogo campaign.  Music: "African" by Roberto80z (www.jamendo.com)

story:
MILLIONS LACK SAFE WATER IN GHANA, AFRICA

The glaring reality is we as humans on planet Earth must drink clean water to survive – the human body depends on it. Yet, more than a billion people across the globe don’t have access to safe, clean drinking water. They are forced to collect water from unsafe sources, such as rainfalls, ponds, streams and rivers that are contaminated.

In Ghana, West-Africa, drinking unsafe water is the leading cause of death in children in rural communities before age three. In fact, a child dies every 20 seconds from drinking unsafe water in Ghana. Unsafe water sources breed water-bourne diseases, ill health, and oftentimes, pemature death.

Safe drinking water is indispensable to life and it has been mandated by the United Nations as a human right.   

RWA International’s mission is to save the lives of children and rural communities by purifying polluted water sources with proven clean water technology, thereby eliminating diseases and ill health.

RWA International has collected some heart-wrenching statistics:

  • Over 3,000 children under 5 years of age die annually from polluted water and poor sanitation in Ghana.
  • 3.5 million people in Ghana lack access to an improved water sources.
  • Over 9 million people don’t have access to safe drinking water.
  • 80% of all diseases in most parts of Africa are caused by unsafe water and poor sanitation.
  • The lack of safe water in Ghana results in an economic burden to the country. 

Ghana is largely rural and does not have the capacity to provide safe water from large municipal treatment plants to serve its populace. High costs, hard-to-reach locations and power requirements are barriers to providing solutions to the problem.

A COST-EFFECTIVE SOLUTION EXISTS!

RWA International has studied extensive testing and research to analyze the best water purification systems and technologies that are available to the entire world, and concluded that the Triad Global Water Purification System is without any doubt the best cost-effective, patented technology available to respond to the specific challenges facing Ghana. The system is manufactured in Atlanta, Georgia USA with subsidiaries in Nigeria and South Sudan, Africa.

Features of the Triad Global Water Purification System

  • Uses patented medical technology. Thousands of tiny, hollow fibers filter out contaminates and produce clean pure water.
  • Membrane pore is .04 microns that traps bacteria, viruses, protozoa, cysts, parasites, and eliminates turbidity to yield safe clean water that meets World Health Organization (WHO) standards.
  • Manually operated. Produces clean water immediately after set up.
  • Requires no electricity, no chemicals, lightweight, portable, easy to maintain.
  • No sophisticated monitoring required, and no special skills required to operate the unit.
  • System treats 1,000 liters of water per hour and 10,000 liters per day.
  • Can be set up as a bank of units for high volume water requirements.
  • Expected lifetime 10 years service per unit.

50 Installations in the Next 24 Months

RWA International plans to establish 50 water purification units within the next 24 months in 50 selected rural communities. And, over the next 10 years, to install units in 250 rural communities. Each installation will cost $15,000 U.S. dollars.

Water Purification Installations include:

  • The mobile water purification unit.
  • Water storage tanks for raw water and purified water.
  • A concrete block enclosure with Iron Gate to house and protect the unit.
  • Transportation and per diem costs for volunteers to build the installation.

RWA International will engage the local Chiefs /Community leaders who select the location for each installation, ensuring that raw water is available at that location (e.g. well water, river, lake, etc.). The community is gifted the water purification installation because it is too poor to purchase it. RWA international will provide training to a community representative for the proper service and operation of the system.

HELP SPREAD THE WORD!

One of the biggest challenges is that not enough people know about the water crisis. Use our resources to help share information about the water crisis with your friends and family. Tweet about it. Blog about it. Share it on FaceBook, Google+ and Linkedin. Start conversations. The more people know about it, the more people will help.

RWA International is a new NGO and all donations and funds are going into saving lives by growing and maintaining our water purification programs.

HELP SAVE LIVES! SHARE YOUR LOVE! DONATE TODAY!

The need is urgent! Funds must be raised to meet this challenge. Every 20 seconds a child dies from unsafe drinking water. Give the gift of life! Share your love. Please be generous in your donations. Join us. Together we can build a better world and achieve greatness!

The best perk is not materialistic, but the heart-warming feeling you give yourself by sharing your love, and knowing you are fulfilling an indispensible role in saving a child’s life. That is the best reward and feeling in the world you can give yourself! It’s a reward that builds compassion and true character!

story:
Summary

My name is Nicki, and I am an adult with Aspergers Syndrome and ADHD. I wanted to become a special education teacher so that I could help kids with learning differences to have a better school experience than I had when I was growing up.

But when I started working in schools, I became frustrated with the way that kids who learned differently were treated. Even in early childhood and kindergarten classrooms, children are expected to spend a lot of time sitting down and being quiet. With large numbers of children, and increasingly strict academic expectations, early childhood teachers often spend a large portion of their time teaching children to be quiet and compliant, rather than actually helping children to discover the world around them. This is a poor way to set the foundation for a lifetime of learning!

I decided to start a preschool program in which children are allowed to learn in their own unique ways. This program is geared towards children who may not meet the requirements for early intervention services, but who have had, or would most likely have, negative experiences in traditional preschool programs. However, all children, with or without special needs, are welcome. Instead of subscribing to a specific learning model, we'll remain flexible, so that we can meet the individual needs of each child. 

We have additional programs to meet the needs of the community, as well. For instance, our open play hours provide an accepting, sensory-rich environment for children with and without special needs to have fun and learn social skills. Our monthly respite days give parents and caregivers a much-needed break, and offer extra enrichment to the children. Our family nights create a feeling of community for parents and children alike. 

In the future, I hope to add tutoring and special interest clubs for older children, and possibly add a full-time primary school classroom. 


My Goals For The Children I'll Work With

  • They'll develop their curiosity and a strong desire to learn more, even when not being required to by a teacher. 
  • They'll develop a love of literature.
  • They'll understand their own strengths, and the ways that they learn best.
  • They'll be accepting, and appreciative, of differences in themselves and others. 
  • They'll feel a sense of belonging and responsibility, in their community, and in the world. 


What We Need 

I have a business plan, a timeline, and funds to purchase equipment and supplies for the classroom. I intend to rent a space and begin setting it up in June, open for drop-in hours by late July, and have the first preschool program start in the beginning of September. 

What I am asking for from supporters is funding for the first two to three months rent in a retail space. In the Portland area, according to my research, the most affordable space would be somewhere between $1500 and $2500. These funds would give me a head start, enabling me to get the program set up and ready before I open it up to the public. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have a single dollar to spare, you can still help out! Just spread the word by sharing this project with your friends. You can also "like" us on Facebook (http://www.facebook.com/overtherainbow111) and ask everyone you know to do the same!

story:
What is Girls on the Run? 

Girls on the Run® is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization dedicated to creating a world where every girl knows and activates her limitless potential and is free to boldly pursue her dreams.

Meeting twice a week in small teams of 8-20 girls, we teach life skills through dynamic, interactive lessons and running games. The 24-lesson curriculum is taught by certified Girls on the Run coaches and includes three parts: understanding ourselves, valuing relationships and teamwork and understanding how we connect with and shape the world at large.

Running is used to inspire and motivate girls, encourage lifelong health and fitness.  It builds confidence through accomplishment. Important social, psychological, and physical skills and abilities are also developed and reinforced throughout the program. At each season's conclusion, the girls and their running buddies complete a 5k running event which gives them a tangible sense of achievement as well as a framework for setting and achieving life goals. The result—making the seemingly impossible, possible, and teaching girls that they can.

The Mission: 
To inspire girls to be joyful, healthy and confident using a fun, experience-based curriculum which creatively integrates running.

How does it work? 
In order to start a council in Moore County, we need to raise $7,500 for the start-up fees alone. Any little bit counts and we hope that if you are excited by this mission, please consider contributing to our fundraiser.

If we get the approval from Girls on the Run International, and are able to raise our start-up fees, we will be able to offer programs for girls in grades 3-5 and 6-8. The cost of the 10-week program is nominal, and scholarships are available for girls who do not have the financial ability to join otherwise. 

How can I learn more? 
Check out the Girls on the Run International Website for more information. To learn more about the council in Moore County and how you can get involved, please email Kelly at kellyekilgore@yahoo.com. To make this happen in our community, the need is greater than just financial support. We are looking for adult role models to help by sharing their time and talent as we get this project underway!

The Passion Behind the Project

The idea to start a Girls on the Run Council in Moore County was the brainchild of local resident Kelly Kilgore. Read more about Kelly's inspiration and vision: 
As a mom of two girls in elementary school, I continually evaluate how my girls are raised, only wanting to shape them into the confident, beautiful women that I see them as.  I want girls to realize their potential whatever it may be.  As the greater Moore County area  grows with younger families and children, I want to be able to give back in a way that I can easily connect to.  
 Girls on the Run  reminded me of what helped me become confident.  Personally, as a young girl, I was influenced by everyone's opinion.  Because of that, my confidence was never strong.  But Cross Country was where I began to build self esteem -  running a race made me feel strong.  Young girls are easily influenced by their surroundings on a day-to-day basis, and I want each opportunity to be a positive one.  Girls on the Run puts these ideas together.  And because of my past, I was immediately drawn to finding out more.  
This is the beginning of this journey for me.  I am excited to influence other girls into becoming strong women.  I appreciate your support.  Thank you.

story:
Summary

The goal of Accessibility Now! is to help everyone be able to fully participate in all communal events at Congregation Beth Sholom.

Congregation Beth Sholom (CBS) is a friendly Modern Orthodox synagogue located in Providence, RI. The lower level of the building is not wheelchair accessible. This makes it impossible for those with mobility issues to go to most of the community events including kiddushes, dinners, and Bar/Bat Mitzvah celebrations. It also limits how much the family members can participate.  We are working to make CBS fully accessible and need your help!


What We Need

 We need $30,000 to create a new entrance that will connect directly to the lower level without using stairs.  Any extra funds will go towards the capital account. 
In addition to the perks described here, every donor who gives at least $250 and does not choose to remain anonymous will be listed in a framed Donor List next to the accessible entrance.

The Impact

This will help many members and guests- people in wheelchairs, the elderly who have difficulty with stairs, families with infants, and anyone else with mobility issues.  This will also help their families - who often are not able to attend events because their loved one can't be there with them. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Please get the word out!  Let your family, friends, and acquaintances know and encourage them to donate!

Have you ever dreamed to have any supernatural ability? From this very moment energy is in your hands.

We introduce you HandEnergy device which is able to simplify our lives. Since that moment you are free from searching for sockets, cause energy is in our hands!

About VAGA

HandEnergy is your personal generator of endless energy. It means that you can produce it everywhere you want. HandEnergy is compact and easy device. Produce, accumulate and use!

 

 

 

 

 

 

How it works?

Nice work. 

 

On this video you can see how we have produced our first prototipes.
 

 

 

 

 

Choose any colour for your personal HandEnergy!

 

Our mission

 

If we gain more than 800 000$ we are aiming to take care about communities who have no access to electricity or suffer from problems with electric power. We are going to provide Hand Energy devices to people in need so they can always easily produce energy for basic needs of their families.


We would love to invite you to become a part of movement with a great purpose that is shared all over the developed countries, let's give power to the people!


When you donate money to the project you have your personal device, producing energy to yourself and helping others to have it!

About team and why we need your help

 

 

 

We are a group of creators from different professions, but we are united by one project and one big idea.

Right now we have a prepared prototype which passed through analyses and tests successfully.

If you have questions, you can always write on our email support@vaga.company

Our website

story:
Short Summary

We are creating a space that will be a haven for the community to socialize and engage. A place where everyone feels comfortable hanging out with friends after work. A place where anyone, particularly ladies, could walk in on their own and feel welcome to hang out by themselves.

A unique, cozy space featuring craft brews, wines for every budget, and locally sourced small plates with delicious global flavors.

A place that has a local ‘‘Mom and Pop” feel, but in our case it’s a “Mom and Mom” business.  We found the ideal spot in our local Oakland neighborhood (Thornhill) where there are no other places for people to gather. The neighborhood where both our kids went to the school. A neighborhood and community we bonded with creating lifelong friends.

We began working on the space back in November 2014. We felt the love from friends and family as they came out to help us with the first stages of remodeling.

As often happens, our plans got changed along the way. Originally we were only going to serve drinks, but while working with the City of Oakland, plans changed and now we plan to serve food as well.  A kitchen wasn’t in our original budget. Now in order serve our patrons, we need to build a kitchen.

WE NEED A KITCHEN!

That’s when we decided to launch our campaign. So far we have done it all by ourselves. We have collected second-hand materials and fixtures from places that give back to communities such as: ReStore - Habitat for Humanity, St. Vincent De Paul, Uhuru and Urban Furniture. Many days and nights have been spent doing mostly cosmetic changes tiling floors, painting walls, building out the bar etc. 

  What if we don’t ask for help?

      Quite frankly we can ONLY make it happen with help from our community!

What's next?

We are really ‘can do’ folks and now it's time to hire the pros to finish up the job. Hiring pros means paying the pros for their invaluable expertise for plumbing, electrical, permits etc. It all gets pretty expensive.

We will shower you with perks!

For our tremendous funders (YOU!) we’ve come up with some stellar perks! Please check out all the perks over there on the right. 

Just saying thank you isn't enough, we really want to shout it out LOUD! That shout out can be found on our 'Wall of Gratitude' tab on on Duvin website, where it will sit forever!


Check out this beautiful Duvin tasting glass. This is available for all our local supporters to come by and pick up. Check the perks on the right that include the glass.

                       

Here are wonderful t-shirts that feature the Funders Club supporters. For all contributors of Duvin Family Member perk and above, your name will be added to the back of all the shirts.

T-shirts come in both fitted styles for ladies

.......and a regular t-shirt cut.


... and gratitude.

We can’t express enough our immense gratitude for what your contribution means to us. As people who have always been on the other side of fundraising for others, for many important causes, asking for funds for ourselves does feel somewhat uncomfortable. We have gone back and forth contemplating every angle of our business before launching this campaign.

Claudia Ward & Lisa McFadin - Founding Partners of Duvin

Challenges

There are always risks when you step outside your comfort zone. Yes, it may be a challenge to start a new business. But it’s also exciting. As each challenge presents itself, we find a solution or the right person to solve it.  After starting many successful projects (not just in Oakland, but also overseas) we have learned that a new venture can bring joy and excitement that outweighs the risk and challenges. And for you the funder, we guarantee you that every dime will be spent with integrity to bring our idea to fruition.

Other Ways You Can Help

There are many ways to help other than making a financial contribution. Please use some of the share buttons on the site to get the word out to your people through social media or email.

story:
We love Ireland...We love New England...We love Beer

We are a nano-brewery making fine craft brew - we are not an idea - we are REAL

We use genuine imported Irish Barley Malt and fuse it with local New England grown products (i.e. honey, maple syrup, berries so far... more to come!)

We are looking to expand operations through the purchase of fermenters, kegs and keg washing equipment

The brewery is up and running and we are in 120+ stores/bars/restaurants in NH (so far). We also have a great taproom where thirsty people have been coming in to enjoy our offerings and listen to great Live Irish music.

Operations have been MAXED OUT and we keep getting requests for more beer

So....we are looking to you - our brothers and sisters in brew - for support to get to the next level - Help us get the brew to you!

We need $15,000 to purchase the following:
  • Fermenter  ($4K)
  • Bottling Machine ($10K)
  • Kegs ($1K)
In return for your help, we have GREAT perks for you - anything from a sticker or pint glass to a food pairing dinner with 10 of your friends!

If we don't reach our goal we will purchase whatever we can with the funds raised (i.e. instead of 2 fermenters we will only get one for now)

 We have raised funds in the past through a Kickstarter and promised to get our brewery up and running - that is what we did - a plaque with our original supporters hangs on the taproom wall


There are  some risks with expanding and it is a lot of hard work. But we have come this far and we are definitely up for the challenge. We are passionate about our beer and want to share it with as many people as possible!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute right now , you can help in other ways:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Cheers!

Michael and Louise

story:
For the month of March, DPS is raising money for a charity called The Arc. The Arc is a charity determined to help those with intellectual and developmental disabilities (I/DD). They fight for the rights of those with I/DD as well as provide them with much needed services like employment programs, healthcare, education, and so much more. They believe that individuals are defined by their strengths, not their disabilities.

With your donation, you would be helping them assure that children with I/DD receive the support they need to succeed in school, be happy at home, and live their life as a happy child. Your donation will also help them make sure that adults with I/DD are capable of living a life that they would like to live. Most importantly, your donation will help The Arc make sure that anyone with I/DD is not treated any different than you or I.


We are in no way affiliated with the Arc.  We are just a group of friends that wish to make a good difference.

story:
"But now ask the beasts and let them teach you; and the birds and let them tell you." Job 12:7

So here's my story. I am a 24-year young lady with a heart as big as this world for animals, especially horses. It's something about their smell, their presence, the way they move. Their eyes, those eyes you can look into and it makes the entire world disappear and every problem you ever had is no longer a problem; you quickly lose yourself to a massive animal staring back at you, trusting you to take care of it and treat it like the angels they are. I encourage you to go find a horse if you are having a bad day and sit patiently in a chair for 15 minutes and watch them. You won’t believe how fast your day turns around.

I grew up working with horses and many other animals; playing with them throughout my childhood grew into saving misfits, training them alongside my own, and finding better homes for the ones I couldn’t afford to keep. My skill grew and I even attended college for several years hoping I would become a vet- I wanted to save every animal that I could get my hands on. After experiencing the death of some of the animals I just couldn’t save I decided I was not cut out to be a veterinarian. Circumstances discontinued my college pursuit, but my love for animals and desire to improve both their quality of life and the lives of those who own them has only grown.

Horses are extremely therapeutic animals, and have been proven to decrease blood pressure, lower heart rate, relieve stress, tension, and anxiety, which has a lot to do with why using horses for therapy is becoming more and more common. Not to mention, caring for them has direct health benefits by burning calories. For an average size person just grooming a horse can burn up to 422 calories/hour, and moderate exercise while riding a horse can burn up to 457 calories/hour! The more I learn about them, and the more I grow with them, the more driven I am to share all the gifts these amazing creatures hold for us.

Finally, after being out of school for two years, I decided to take the leap. I am fighting off debt for college loans, but I can’t wait any longer, so I decided to start my own business!

“Angels Among Us” is an equine boarding facility where I also train and teach lessons. It's a place that unwanted horses can come and receive training and be given a second chance at life. I am also going to be hosting pony parties so that every kid has the opportunity on their birthday to make their dreams come true and can share it with their friends! Facilities include two arenas, one indoor and one outdoors, each available to rent. The arenas provide the perfect place to host clinics, shows, and any other horse related activities. It's in a perfect location right in the middle of town, very convenient for kids and adults to come by after school or work. This business is meant to help not only horses, but people! Help get away from all the stress and anxiety of the everyday life, and at the same time you will be returning the favor for our horses. When I am able to afford it, I would also like to purchase all the equipment and all the necessary things I need to do therapy by building a barn that is able to properly and safely help disabled people and people with mental illnesses.

Unfortunately, I am not able to get any sort of loan or financial help because of loans that I took out for school. I have always been too independent to ask for money, but I have to make a choice either lose a dream or swallow my pride and ask for help. Well I'm sure you know which one I picked. So here I am asking you to donate, which will help me to not only start “Angels Among Us,” but it will help me help others, horses and people alike. Once it gets up and going it will be self-sustaining business, it's just getting started that I need a little help with.

No one likes asking for money, or help in general. But we all need it sometimes! I know that I was given a gift with these animals, and I am determined to see it through to help as many horses and people as possible. Training is the difference between a $250 horse and a $5,000 horse. Training is the difference between a dangerous 1200-pound beast and a cooperative animal willing to do as you ask. Training is the difference between a horse going to slaughter and a horse that is happy and living a high quality of life, and able to serve others.

I have the perfect facility, experience, and education to be that difference. I take in unwanted, neglected, or abused horses and give them the proper training to set them up for success with someone that will love them and treat them the way they are meant to be treated. It is also perfect for educating people on how to properly care for, ride, and teach their horses so that they can share the same great benefits safely. But I need your help.

Expenses

$1000 - Sand for arena

$2000- Hay for horses

$1000- Insurance

$1000- Vet costs for rescue horses(Dental, Coggins, Chiropractor, Farrier)

$600- Arena Drag

$500- Horse Blankets for Rescues

$500- Natural Horsemanship Equipment for training

story:
My name is Ron Riley, President of RJ Riley & Company. My company has managed and/or created over 90 events over the years including the signature entrepreneurial event, American Dream Seekers.

The purpose of this campaign is to help continue the mission of mentoring and coaching entrepreneurs of all ages in this competition; ultimately allowing Semi-Finalists to have the opportunity to compete for networking opportunities and to make meaningful connections as well as the chance to pitch their business or product to a panel of prominent business leaders for the chance to receive equity funding. 

This event is important for Southwest Florida as it attracts people from all over the world to compete in the Semi-Final Round on event day; showcasing the region as fertile ground for business development and growth throughout the year, adding value to the economy and spotlighting the region as being open to new business.

The funds will help promote this event globally and subsidize the platform and infrastructure to give the greatest opportunity of success for all competitors and for this region.

We are seeking $87,000 to partially fund this project. These funds will help defray expenses including marketing, advertising and promoting the event internationally during the first qualifying Round 1 submission stage that opened on February 1 and closes on June 30 and the subsequent Rounds which include intense coaching and mentoring to all applicants. In addition, the funds will help defray the costs of renting a ballroom, breakout session rooms, audio visual production, videography, staffing and much more. By doing so, everyone can benefit including all contestants, exhibitors and sponsors, investors and interested parties, and the Southwest Florida economy.

Everyone continues to be amazed and proud at the impact that American Dream Seekers had for all those that took part in the experience last year. Even now, we continue to get feedback from so many entrepreneurs about the doors that were and continue to be opened as well as the funding that was committed, (over $100,000), and even more money is still being negotiated.

Your investment and belief in American Dream Seekers can help change lives through new business and product development for entrepreneurs of all ages all over the world. Your investment can also provide you or your business with some outstanding perks. Please review the sidebar to the right of this story for the various levels of participation and all that you will receive.

Corporate sponsorships are also available and can be customized for your company. Please email or call for more details.

Thank you for considering this opportunity. 

Your help at any level is very much appreciated.

Ron Riley

ronaldjriley@gmail.com

story:
Cliquez ici pour lire en francais !

Who am I?

My name is Michael Kazadi, I’m a second year student studying Business Administration at Oglethorpe University in Atlanta, Georgia. I'm 19 years old, American by birth and of Congolese heritage. I’ve lived in eight different countries including France, five African nations and Germany. I have also visited over 27 countries on four continents.

As a young entrepreneur, I’m concerned with issues related to malnutrition, Africa’s growth, global environmental challenges and globalization. The potentials in rearing Congolese crickets quickly became a project that captured my attention. Implementing this project in Africa and taking expertise from the West would impact regions in Africa beyond borders.

What do I intend to do and how?

I want to install a research unit that will develop different rearing methods for the cricket specie Brachytrupes membranaceus in Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo, in order to farm it commercially for direct human consumption in Kinshasa and possibly beyond. Crickets are a popular dish in the DRC. Brachytrupes membranaceus is a cricket specie found in more than 10 countries in the central and southern African region. The research will be conducted through a research plan crafted with the entomologist Marianne Shockley PhD, of the University of Georgia’s (UGA) Department of Entomology. The project will be implemented by a team of students and researchers from Institut Superieur Agroveterinaire de Kimwenza (ISAV), the leading research institute in agribusiness in Kinshasa, and UGA. The whole process is benefiting assistance from the Food and Agriculture Organization’s (FAO) office in Kinshasa, as a facilitator.

The research will last 2 years (December 2015 – December 2017). I will use its results to farm the cricket intensively and commercialize it in the city of Kinshasa.

Why is this project important?

Crickets are a sustainable and healthy source of protein, consumed by 70% of Kinshasa’s inhabitants. They are currently collected by hand, which causes their exorbitant price. My project aims to make them affordable through a profitable venture.

Compared to traditional sources of protein, crickets are much more efficient and eco-friendly. Only 2kg of feed must be given to crickets to obtain 1kg of protein. This is a much better ratio than cattle (10kg of feed for 1kg of protein); sheep (6kg of feed for 1kg of protein); or pigs (4kg of feed for 1 kg of protein). Also, crickets emit considerably fewer greenhouse gases (livestock rearing is responsible for 18% of greenhouse gas emissions), do not require as much land, and can be fed with organic waste streams. Furthermore, they only demand 8 liters of water to produce 1 kg of protein, against 8000 liters for 1 kg for cattle and 1200 liters for 1 kg for chicken. 

One of the goals of the research is to find the best combination of feed from the Congolese biomass to insure a production that is natural, of high quality and more competitive compared to other animal proteins.

Crickets are consumed by 70% of Kinshasa’s 10 million inhabitants, and by two-thirds of the DRC’s 70 million inhabitants. The only way it has been provided is by having gatherers individually collect the crickets. This results in a very limited supply that is sold at a costly retail price – between $25 and $50 per kilo depending on the season (below is a photograph of President Chirac visiting a market in Kinshasa). It’s a lot more expensive, compared to the retail price of the common house cricket (Acheta Domesticus) in the USA ($10 to $15), and in Thailand ($18 to $21). 

                                       


Rearing the cricket can also limit the environmental damages caused by cricket gathering, since gatherers destroy the surrounding environment (plants, branches, etc.) that may hinder their search, when digging to find crickets. It will also prevent the species extinction.

Finally, rearing the cricket can be a mean to reduce poverty. If crickets are reared intensively, its current gatherers will start supplying farmers with plants to feed the crickets. This will enable them to obtain a stable income, which is better than the limited, sporadic income they get from crickets that are painstakingly harvested by hand, and only available during nine months out of twelve. With a year-long supply of crickets in the market, each reseller in the chain (whom are mostly women) will benefit from a constant income, compared to the current state of uncertainty caused by cricket gathering. Insect rearing will also be promoted in the DRC.

How am I going to do the research?

The research unit will be based at ISAV, and conducted under my leadership by a team of students and researchers from UGA and ISAV (below is a photograph of myself visiting a laboratory at ISAV with its Director Mr. Ntangu, in June 2015).They will follow the research plan referred to above.

                                       

Having American students collaborate with African students, will enable both parties to share their cultures and know-how in a supportive environment. This will combine American and Asian production practices, to produce goods that are geared towards African consumers. I also intend to add students/scientists/organizations from France and the Netherlands to the team of researchers.

Why I need your help?

My goal is to build a profitable business model focused on sustainability. The research unit is the first step before scaling-up production and commercialization.

By donating money for this research, you directly contribute to the promotion of entomophagy, sustainability, innovation, youth economic empowerment and African development.

The campaign’s goal is to raise $38,000 to fund the following activities:

1.  Equipment and material for the research.

2.  Consultants/researchers.

3.  Traveling costs to inspect the research.

4.  Local expenses (Administrative fees)

5.  Crowdfunding fees (Indiegogo fees, gifts, …)

I am also advised by a law firm in Atlanta, to ensure a smooth collaboration between all the parties involved in this venture.

Relative to various levels of contribution, four different gifts will be offered to donors. Two of them – the bronze cricket, and the framed tapestry – are specially crafted by Congolese craftsmen.

If the contributions exceed the initial goal, the project will use the surplus to expand research options, and to provide appropriate equipment to current women gatherers who are also planters. 

What are the risks and how are they mitigated?

The expected risks are not so much on the scientific side, as they are in the business environment in Kinshasa. Working with reliable people, building an effective team and managing possible administrative inconveniences are the biggest challenges. The FAO’s role as a facilitator is helping me manage these risks. I can also rely on my personal network, and on my social experience with people of Kinshasa.

An advisory board is currently being formed with representatives of the U.S. and Congolese entomology community.

What happens after the research?

During the research, all contributors will be updated on the project’s progress on a regular basis (at least every 3 months).

Once we will have mastered the appropriate methods to rear the cricket specie in captivity, the research unit will automatically shift into a production unit through a local subsidiary of Tropicalis LLC, the US entity I have created in Atlanta, GA.

The next step will be scaling up the business to its huge potential. We welcome you to support this exciting project.

For more information contact me by email at mikekazadi@gmail.com; Phone: +1 678 462 6362

Francais 

Qui suis-je ?

Mon nom est Michael Kazadi, je suis étudiant en deuxième année de gestion (Administration des affaires) à l'Université Oglethorpe à Atlanta aux USA. J’ai 19 ans, je suis américain de naissance, Congolais par mes parents et j’ai vécu dans 8 pays différents, dont la France, 5 pays d’Afrique et l’Allemagne. J’ai également visité plus de 27 pays sur 4 continents.

En tant que jeune entrepreneur vivant dans une période critique de l’histoire de l’humanité en ce qui concerne la malnutrition, l’ambition d’émergence de l'Afrique, les défis environnementaux de la planète et la mondialisation ; l’élevage du grillon congolais a rapidement capté mon intérêt. Il s'agit d'un projet qui se fera en Afrique, avec l'expertise de l'Ouest,  et dont l’impact peut rayonner au-delà de ses frontières.

Ce que je veux faire et comment je veux le faire ? 

Je veux installer à Kinshasa, en RDC, une unité de recherche qui permettra d'élaborer des méthodes d'élevage intensif pour l’espèce de grillon appelée Brachytrupes membranaceus, afin de le commercialiser pour le marché de la consommation humaine à Kinshasa et éventuellement au delà. Le grillon est un met populaire en RDC. Le Brachytrupes membranaceus est une espèce de grillon que l’on trouve dans plus de 10 pays en Afrique centrale et australe. La recherche sera effectuée à travers un plan de recherche que j’ai conçu avec l'entomologiste Marianne Shockley du Département d’entomologie de l'Université de Georgie (UGA). Son exécution sera assurée sous ma supervision, par une équipe d'étudiants et de chercheurs de UGA et de l'Institut Supérieur Agrovétérinaire de Kimwenza (ISAV), un des principaux instituts universitaires de recherche dans le domaine agro-industriel à Kinshasa. L’ensemble du processus bénéficie  également de l’assistance du bureau de l'Organisation des Nations Unies pour l'Agriculture et l'Alimentation (FAO) à Kinshasa, dans un rôle de facilitateur.

La recherche durera 2 ans (décembre 2015 – décembre 2017), et je vais utiliser ses résultats pour démarrer une production intensive du grillon afin de le commercialiser dans la ville de Kinshasa.

Pourquoi le projet est-il pertinent ?

Les grillons sont une source de protéines durable et nutritive, et ils sont consommés par 70 % des 10 millions d'habitants de Kinshasa. Jusqu’à ce jour, ils ne sont issus que de la collecte manuelle, ce qui explique leur prix exorbitant. Mon projet contribuera à rendre le grillon plus accessible, à travers une entreprise rentable.

Par rapport aux sources traditionnelles de protéine, le grillon est beaucoup plus efficient et respectueux de l'environnement. Il faut seulement 2 kg d'aliments pour obtenir 1 kg de protéines de grillons. Il s'agit d'un ratio beaucoup plus intéressant que pour les bovins (10 kg d'aliments pour 1 kg de protéines) ; le mouton, (6 kg d'aliments pour 1 kg de protéines) ; ou le porc (4 kg d'aliments pour 1 kg de protéines). Par ailleurs, les grillons émettent infiniment moins de  gaz à effet de serre que le bétail (le bétail contribue pour 18 % dans les émissions de gaz  à effet de serre), leur élevage nécessite peu de terre et peut recourir aux déchets organiques courants comme aliments. En outre, 1 litre d’eau seulement suffit pour produire 1 kg de protéines de grillon, contre 8000 litres pour 1 kg de bœuf et 1200 litres pour 1 kg de poulet.

Le grillon est consommé par 70 % de la population de Kinshasa, qui s’élève à environ 10 millions d’habitants, et par les 2/3 des 70 millions de Congolais. L’approvisionnement en grillons est exclusivement assuré par la cueillette individuelle, ce qui explique les faibles quantités disponibles et le prix élevé au détail (entre 25 $ et 50 $ le kilo selon la saison). C’est beaucoup trop cher comparé au prix de revente au kilo du grillon domestique produit aux USA (10 $ à 15 $) ou en Thaïlande (18 $ à 21 $). Ci-dessous est une photo du président Chirac en train de visiter un marché à Kinshasa: 

                                       

L’un des enjeux de la recherche est de trouver la meilleure combinaison d’aliments issus de la biomasse congolaise pour assurer une production naturelle, de haute qualité et plus compétitive par rapport aux autres protéines animales.

L’élevage du grillon peut aussi contribuer à limiter les dommages environnementaux causés par sa collecte sauvage. Motivés par les revenus qu’il procure, les collecteurs de grillon n’hésitent pas à détruire les différents obstacles à sa capture (plantes, branches, etc.) et creusent parfois en profondeur pour en trouver, au risque d’aggraver la détérioration des sols et même de menacer la survie de l’espèce.

Enfin, l'élevage du grillon peut contribuer efficacement à la réduction de la pauvreté. Avec l’élevage intensif du grillon, les personnes qui actuellement le collectent artisanalement pourront devenir des fournisseurs d’aliments pour les éleveurs de grillons et s’assurer ainsi des revenus stables et prévisibles. Ceci est préférable aux maigres revenus issus de la cueillette pénible et aléatoire du grillon. Avec l’élevage, la chaîne de valeur sera étendue aux revendeurs, dont la majorité sont des femmes, qui s’assureront également des revenus stables. Enfin, l’élevage du grillon se verra progressivement promu au sein des populations en RDC. 

Comment je vais faire la recherche ?

L’unité de recherche sera basée à l'ISAV. Je conduirai la recherche avec une équipe d'étudiants et de chercheurs de UGA et l’ISAV (ci-dessous est une photo de moi visitant un laboratoire à l’ISAV, en compagnie de son Directeur, M. Ntangu en juin 2015).  L’équipe suivra le plan de recherche conçu à cet effet.

                                           

Mettre en relation des étudiants et chercheurs des USA et de l’Afrique est un aspect intéressant qui permettra aux deux parties de partager leurs cultures et savoir-faire dans un environnement serein. Le projet combinera les pratiques de production américaines et asiatiques, pour un produit destiné à des consommateurs africains. J'ai également l'intention de collaborer avec des scientifiques français et néerlandais.

Pourquoi j'ai besoin de votre aide ?

Mon but est de construire un modèle d'affaire rentable et axé sur la durabilité. L'unité de recherche en est la première étape avant la mise à l’échelle de la production et de la commercialisation.

A travers vos dons, vous contribuerez à la promotion de l’entomophagie, de la durabilité, de l’innovation, de la responsabilisation économique des jeunes et au développement de l’Afrique.

Je lance une campagne en vue de récolter  38.000 $ pour le financement des activités suivantes :

1.  Matériel et équipement  pour la recherche.

2. Frais de consultance/recherche.

3. Frais de voyage au titre de la supervision de la recherche.

4. Dépenses locales (frais administratifs).

5. Charges liées au financement participatif (Indiegogo, cadeaux, ...)

En fonction des différents niveaux des contributions, quatre types de cadeaux seront offerts aux donateurs. Deux de ces cadeaux – le grillon en bronze et la tapisserie en velours- ont été spécialement faits par des artisans Congolais.

Si les contributions dépassent l'objectif initial,  le projet utilisera le surplus pour élargir les options de recherche, et aussi pour fournir des équipements appropriés aux femmes qui collectent le grillon, car elles sont aussi des planteuses.

Quels sont les risques identifiés et comment les contrôler?

Les principaux risques portent moins sur l’aspect scientifique que sur l’environnement des affaires à Kinshasa. Identifier des collaborateurs fiables, construire une équipe efficace et gérer d’éventuelles pesanteurs administratives constituent les principaux défis. Le rôle de facilitateur que joue la FAO m'aide à  réduire ces risques. Je peux également m’appuyer sur mon réseau personnel de contacts et sur mon expérience sociale de la population kinoise.

Pour le suivi du projet, un comité consultatif est en cours de constitution avec des représentants de la communauté d’entomologie des USA et de la RDC.

Je suis également conseillé par un cabinet d’avocats d’Atlanta, afin d’assurer une bonne collaboration avec les différents partenaires impliqués dans ce projet.

Que se passera-t-il après la recherche ?

Pendant la recherche, l’ensemble des contributeurs recevront une mise à jour régulière sur le projet (au minimum chaque trimestre).

Une fois que nous maîtriserons la méthode appropriée pour l'élevage de l'espèce de grillon congolais, l'unité de recherche se transformera automatiquement en une unité de production et de commercialisation, à travers une filiale locale de Tropicalis LLC, l’entité américaine que j’ai créée à Atlanta, GA.

La prochaine étape consistera à développer l’affaire à l’échelle de son haut potentiel. Nous vous invitons à soutenir la réalisation de ce projet passionnant.

Pour plus d'informations contactez moi par email : mikekazadi@gmail.com ; Téléphone : +1 678 462 6362
story_txt:
Cliquez ici pour lire en francais !Who am I?My name is Michael Kazadi, I’m a second year student studying Business Administration at Oglethorpe University in Atlanta, Georgia. I'm 19 years old, American by birth and of Congolese heritage. I’ve lived in eight different countries including France, five African nations and Germany. I have also visited over 27 countries on four continents.As a young entrepreneur, I’m concerned with issues related to malnutrition, Africa’s growth, global environmental challenges and globalization. The potentials in rearing Congolese crickets quickly became a project that captured my attention. Implementing this project in Africa and taking expertise from the West would impact regions in Africa beyond borders.
What do I intend to do and how?
I want to install a research unit that will develop different
rearing methods for the cricket specie Brachytrupes membranaceus in Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo, in order to farm it
commercially for direct human consumption in Kinshasa and possibly beyond. Crickets are a popular dish in the DRC. Brachytrupes membranaceus is a cricket specie found in more than 10
countries in the central and southern African region. The research will be conducted
through a research plan crafted with the entomologist Marianne Shockley PhD, of the
University of Georgia’s (UGA) Department of Entomology. The project will be implemented by a team of students and researchers from Institut Superieur Agroveterinaire
de Kimwenza (ISAV), the leading research institute in agribusiness in Kinshasa,
and UGA. The whole process is benefiting assistance from the Food and Agriculture Organization’s (FAO) office in
Kinshasa, as a facilitator.
The research will last 2 years (December 2015 – December 2017).
I will use its results to farm the cricket intensively and commercialize it in
the city of Kinshasa.
Why is this project important?
Crickets are a sustainable and healthy source of protein,
consumed by 70% of Kinshasa’s inhabitants. They are currently collected by
hand, which causes their exorbitant price. My project aims to make them affordable through a profitable venture. 
Compared to traditional sources of protein, crickets are much
more efficient and eco-friendly. Only 2kg of feed must be given to crickets to
obtain 1kg of protein. This is a much better ratio than cattle (10kg of feed
for 1kg of protein); sheep (6kg of feed for 1kg of protein); or pigs (4kg of
feed for 1 kg of protein). Also, crickets emit considerably fewer greenhouse
gases (livestock rearing is responsible for 18% of greenhouse gas emissions),
do not require as much land, and can be fed with organic waste streams. Furthermore,
they only demand 8 liters of water to produce 1 kg of protein, against 8000 liters
for 1 kg for cattle and 1200 liters for 1 kg for chicken. One of the goals of the research is to find the best combination of feed from the Congolese biomass to insure a production that is natural, of high quality and more competitive compared to other animal proteins.

 
 

 
 
Crickets are consumed
by 70% of Kinshasa’s 10 million inhabitants, and by two-thirds of the DRC’s 70
million inhabitants. The only way it has been provided is by having gatherers
individually collect the crickets. This results in a very limited supply that is
sold at a costly retail price – between $25 and $50 per kilo depending on
the season (below is a photograph of President Chirac visiting a market in Kinshasa). It’s a lot more expensive, compared to the retail price of the common
house cricket (Acheta Domesticus) in
the USA ($10 to $15), and in Thailand ($18 to $21).                                        
Rearing the cricket can also limit the environmental damages
caused by cricket gathering, since gatherers destroy the surrounding environment (plants, branches, etc.) that may hinder their search, when digging to find crickets. It will also prevent the species extinction.
Finally, rearing the cricket can be a mean to reduce poverty. If crickets are reared
intensively, its current gatherers will start supplying farmers with plants to
feed the crickets. This will enable them to obtain a stable income, which is
better than the limited, sporadic income they get from crickets that are painstakingly
harvested by hand, and only available during nine months out of twelve. With a
year-long supply of crickets in the market, each reseller in the chain (whom
are mostly women) will benefit from a constant income, compared to the current
state of uncertainty caused by cricket gathering. Insect rearing will also be
promoted in the DRC.
How am I going to do the research?

 
 
The research unit
will be based at ISAV, and conducted under my leadership by a team of students
and researchers from UGA and ISAV (below is a photograph of myself visiting a
laboratory at ISAV with its Director Mr. Ntangu, in June 2015).They will follow the research plan referred to above.                                       
Having American students collaborate with African students,
will enable both parties to share their cultures and know-how in a supportive environment. This will combine American and Asian production practices, to
produce goods that are geared towards African consumers. I also intend to add students/scientists/organizations from France and the Netherlands to the team of researchers.
Why I need your help?
My goal is to
build a profitable business model focused on sustainability. The research unit
is the first step before scaling-up production and commercialization.
By donating
money for this research, you directly contribute to the promotion of entomophagy, sustainability,
innovation, youth economic empowerment and African development. 
The campaign’s goal is to raise $38,000 to fund the following activities: 
1. 
Equipment and material for the research.
2. 
Consultants/researchers.
3. 
Traveling costs to inspect the research.
4. 
Local expenses (Administrative fees)
5. 
Crowdfunding fees (Indiegogo fees, gifts, …)I am also advised by a law firm in Atlanta, to ensure a smooth collaboration between all the parties involved in this venture.Relative to various levels of contribution, four different
gifts will be offered to donors. Two of them – the bronze cricket, and the
framed tapestry – are specially crafted by Congolese craftsmen. If the contributions exceed the initial goal, the project will use the surplus to expand research options, and to provide appropriate equipment to current women gatherers who are also planters. 
What are the risks and how are they
mitigated?
The expected
risks are not so much on the scientific side, as they are in the business
environment in Kinshasa. Working with reliable people, building an effective
team and managing possible administrative inconveniences are the biggest
challenges. The FAO’s role as a facilitator is helping me manage these
risks. I can also rely on my personal network, and on my social experience
with people of Kinshasa. An advisory board is currently being formed with representatives of the U.S. and Congolese entomology community.
What happens after the research?
During the research, all contributors will be updated on the
project’s progress on a regular basis (at least every 3 months).
Once we will have mastered the appropriate methods to rear
the cricket specie in captivity, the research unit will automatically shift
into a production unit through a local subsidiary of Tropicalis LLC, the US entity
I have created in Atlanta, GA.
The next step will be scaling up the business to its huge
potential. We welcome you to support this exciting project.For more information contact me by email at mikekazadi@gmail.com; Phone: +1 678 462 6362Francais

sur mon réseau personnel de contacts et sur mon expérience sociale de la
population kinoise.
Pour le suivi du projet, un comité consultatif est en cours de constitution avec des représentants de la communauté d’entomologie des USA et de la
RDC.Je suis également conseillé par un cabinet d’avocats d’Atlanta, afin d’assurer une bonne collaboration avec les différents partenaires impliqués dans ce projet.

Que se passera-t-il après la
recherche ?
Pendant la
recherche, l’ensemble des contributeurs recevront une mise à jour régulière
sur le projet (au minimum chaque trimestre). 
Une fois que nous maîtriserons la
méthode appropriée pour l'élevage de l'espèce de grillon congolais, l'unité de
recherche se transformera automatiquement en une unité de production et de
commercialisation, à travers une filiale locale de Tropicalis LLC, l’entité américaine que j’ai créée à Atlanta, GA.
La prochaine étape consistera à développer
l’affaire à l’échelle de son haut potentiel. Nous vous invitons à soutenir la réalisation de ce projet passionnant.
Pour plus d'informations contactez moi par email : mikekazadi@gmail.com ; Téléphone : +1 678 462 6362

story:
The historic Century Inn located along The National Pike suffered extreme fire damage on August 18, 2015. The community is raising funds to help rebuild The Century Inn. This crowdfunding campaign is managed by a friend of the innkeeper and the Harrington family. If you have any questions, please contact Aram Asarian: info@aramasarian.com -or- 202-465-2749 (Mon-Fri, 9am-5pm)

If you donate, you will have your name engraved on a commemorative plaque. The plaque will reside within The Century Inn once it is rebuilt and become a part of history. 

Please submit your full name as you would like it spelled on the plaque. If you prefer to make an anonymous donation, please select to hide your name on the campaign page when you make your contribution. 

Thank you for your support! 

– The Scenery Hill, Washington County Communities, and the Harrington Family.


CONTRIBUTION LEVELS

Stephen Hill:  $25-$249
Chief Blackhawk:  $250-$1,499
David Bradford:  $1,500-$2,499
Lafayette:  $2,500-$4,999
Albert Gallatin:  $5,000-$9,999
Andrew Jackson:  $10,000+

Please help us rebuild this historic landmark by donating today!

story:
LET THE WATERS ROLL DOWN LIKE A MIGHTY STREAM!

MACoM is looking for rainmakers. 

MACoM is a pluralistic ritual immersion pool built to the highest Halachic standard. It has been designed to meet the needs of the entire Jewish community, no matter what their Jewish background or affiliation, or reason for immersing in the mikvah. 
We value diversity and inclusiveness. MACoM will be a welcoming, safe, and supportive sacred place for all who enter.  Traditionally, people use the mikvah when converting to Judaism, before getting married, or in the monthly sanctification of a marriage or relationship. Today, Jews also turn to this ritual as a powerful way to mark other life occasions, particularly times of joy and celebration, transition and transformation, and time of struggle or loss. For example, an individual might choose to immerse when graduating from school, becoming a bar/bat mitzvah, upon finishing chemotherapy or ending a marriage, or celebrating a milestone birthday.
MACoM is committed to providing high quality, innovative educational programming. Our goal is to foster creative exploration of an ancient ritual, spiritual fulfillment, and Jewish connection. 

What We Need 

MACoM was able to begin construction in May, 2015 thanks to the generous gifts of a few key donors. Now we need to raise $200,000 with at least $50,000 from this campaign in the next 60 days in order to finish construction, open our doors and furnish the building before our ribbon-cutting on November 15.  If you are interested in making a larger gift, please contact info@atlantamikvah.org. All gifts given are tax deductible; MACoM is a registered 501(c)3 non-profit organization.

Your contribution will enable us to:

  • Complete and furnish the building 
  • Fill the immersion pool
  • Purchase bathrobes, towels, and other grooming aids
  • Train mikvah guides to assist those coming to immerse in the mikvah

Impact of MACoM on the Southeast Jewish Community

Your donation will have a ripple effect, touching lives beyond your own in important ways.
MACoM will be a beautiful and welcoming space for conversion to Judaism.
MACoM will be a gateway for connection to Judaism and its rituals, no matter what the individual level of observance or knowledge of Jewish practice.



How can you be a part of MACoM?

  • Help us spread the word by telling your friends!  
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to post on your own social media accounts!
  • Sign up on our website

story:
MSVS is a registered Not for Profit Company (Registration nr: 2015/170143/08) in South Africa that was established on 19 March 2015 as a community organisation. We are starting a project (Purple Bag Project) with the aim to provide a shopping bag full of food for families in need.

This bag will be filled with food enough for 2 weeks for a family of four. We would also like to add to this bag some vegetable seeds so that these families can start planting their own food.

Our aim is to provide (as a start) a bag each to 1000 poor families. That will be 4000 people who will benefit! These families will be identified by churches and civil society organisations in order to make sure it goes to deserving families.

Each bag will cost R300 or approximately $30 to fill. That is about R5.30 per person per day or 53 cents in $ terms.

Please help us to feed some of these families.

story:
Short Summary

Thank you for visiting our page! The BCAC Giving Tree is now in it's 35th year, and we are very excited to begin our 2015 season! For those of you who are not familiar with our program, we provide new, warm clothing to children ages 12 years and under whose families are income eligible in our community. Each year we serve more than 1,200 children and we need your help more than ever this year! Any amount helps to provide warm clothing to the children in our community. 

What We Need 

This year, we are looking for new and innovative ways to gain support for this program, one of them through crowd funding. 

We understand that not everyone is able to get to the mall or able to volunteer, but we wanted to offer a way for people to still help. 

We have set a goal for $5000, all of which will be used to buy a jacket, a pair of boots, a long sleeve shirt/sweatshirt, a pair of pants, and socks, scarves, mittens, hats, etc. for each child in need. Any amount, big or small, will make a difference in in helping children obtain warm clothing this holiday season!

Other Ways You Can Help

We also understand that not everyone may be able to help this holiday season! We ask that you please share this page and help us get the word out to our community! You never know how much impact a simple click of that share button can make! 

Please also note that new and handmade donations can be sent or delivered to our Main office at 1531 East St. in Pittsfield. 

For those of you who wish to make a cash or check donation, we will also accept those at our main office location, or you can mail a check to us as well. 

Our deepest gratitude and warmest wishes,

The BCAC Giving Tree team

story:
Dear people, 

We are convinced that Heroes are willing to change the World but sometimes they just don’t know how. 

Probaid is a problem and solution crowdsourcing platform that crosses borders and knows no boundaries with one goal: to find the best solution for a community problem.

The community will be posting their problems and concerns on how they can help their environment and the power of the vote will dictate the importance of the issue. The top votes will have the ability to create a full campaign opening up a portal of people from across the globe willing to share their solutions. 

Probaid’s Indiegogo campaign stems from a group of Draper University Students that came into a hackathon with no idea of what project they will work on, after deliberating and iterating we have come up with this grandiose problem. For 36 hours we are tasked with creating something not short of AMAZING. 

We now have aspirations of creating a full fledged startup ready to tackle on the worlds problems. Our goal is indeed lofty (from the eyes of non-believers) but innovation has never come from the mind of a pessimist; therefore we set our limits high and refuse to accept nothing less than what our hopeful minds have instilled in us. 

-We are raising $1,000,000 to:

  • Establish a fund/pool to support communities and projects that post on the site. People choose, what gets funded.
  • Finish the developments of the platform (around 6% of total)

If in the event we do raise an amount more than our fingers can count we will donate a chunk of the funds to an organization worthy of this donation (determined by the crowd of course!) and the remainder will go into the development of this startup. Excuse my cliche thoughts but are these words not true? 

We ask all the believers, all the people who were told they could not accomplish something but proved them wrong time and time again to take a chance and see how we can see this idea come to fruition! 

-Your Fellow Heroes
